refnamediv.refpurpose: Bind a server to a service instance

refsect1.title: Description
refsect1.para: The aq bind server command binds a server providing some service to a specific service instance. A service may be provided by a host, a service address of a cluster, or an alias. If the service is provided by a host, it is possible to specify the IP address or the service address where the service is bound to. The difference between the two is that service addresses may float between interfaces (controlled by a software component running on the host), while plain IP addresses are always bound to a specific network interface.

If the --alias option is provided in addition to --host or --cluster, then clients will use the specified ALIAS when they try to connect to the service, but the host/cluster providing the service is still aware of the server binding. If the --alias option is used alone (i.e. neither --host nor --cluster is specified), then the target host/cluster will not be aware of the service binding. This is useful if the configuration of the service itself happens outside of Aquilon/Quattor.

listitem.para: The name of the service instance to bind to.

The name of the host providing the service. If no --ip or --service_address options are specified, then it's up to the template code to decide if the service is provided on any IP address the host may have, or just the primary IP address only. That distinction is meaningful for clients not configured using Aquilon/Quattor; client configuration generated by Aquilon will always use the server's primary IP address.
Specifies the IP address where the service is bound to, if the host has multiple IP addresses. Specifying the --hostname option is mandatory.
The service is provided by a cluster, which usually means there's some high availability or load-balancing solution that manages the service. Specifying the --service_address option is mandatory.

Name of the service address providing the service. Specifying one of the --hostname or --cluster options is mandatory. Binding a service to a service address usually means there is some software component that handles failover and/or load balancing for the service.
Name of the resource group where the service address belongs to. It is meaningful together with the --service_address option only.

Insert the server definition at the given position, instead at the end of the list. This is important if clients of the service care about the order of the servers. The numbering starts from zero, i.e. --position 0 will insert the new entry before any other existing servers. Negative numbers are also allowed and count from the end of the existing server list.
Omitting this option, or specifying a value larger than the number of existing servers, will cause the new server to be added at the end of the list.

If this option is specified alone, then the serivce will be provided by the given alias. Even if the alias points to a host/cluster defined in Aquilon, that host/cluster will not be aware of the binding, and will not automatically configure itself as a server. This is useful if the actual service is maintained/configured outside of Aquilon/Quattor.

If this option is specified together with the --hostname or --cluster options, then the host or cluster will be configured as usual for providing the service, but clients will always use ALIAS when configuring the service.

If the --alias option is specified, then the IP address of the service will not be specified in the client templates, even if it is otherwise known to the broker. Make sure not to use --alias for any services that need to use IP addresses instead of names registered in the DNS. One such example is configuring the DNS resolver itself.
